SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for about five weeks. He has been involved in home renovation projects and has had difficulty maintaining a healthy diet due to the construction in his kitchen. He experiences shortness of breath during physical exertion and occasional slight chest cramps that resolve within an hour. He also reports a slight cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses fatigue, lightheadedness, shortness of breath, and occasional chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Endorses a slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

• Congestive heart failure
• Hypertension

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

• Lasix
• Lisinopril

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Jugular venous distention: 8 cm
• Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur
• Lungs: Fine crackles at bases bilaterally
• Lower extremities: 1+ pitting edema

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive heart failure:
• Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with fatigue, lightheadedness, shortness of breath, and physical exam findings consistent with fluid retention.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once daily. Monitor daily weight and report any weight gain or worsening symptoms. Order a follow-up echocardiogram.

Hypertension:
• Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Continue to record blood pressures at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday when she stumbled and twisted her knee while trying to catch her fall. She denies injuring any other part of her body. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation, currently on digoxin.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

EXAM

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stress. Sensation is intact distally. No calf pain.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee obtained today show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but alignment appears normal.

IMPRESSION

Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain of the right knee.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for re-evaluation, and if not improved, we may obtain an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Lower back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. He presents today with lower back pain that began after lifting heavy boxes on Saturday. He heard a pop and experienced pain, which required lying down for an hour before it was relieved. The pain has been persistent and stiff since then. He has taken Tylenol and ibuprofen and used icy heat for the pain, but with limited relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon. He has difficulty finding a comfortable position for sleeping.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports lower back pain.
Neurological: Reports tingling in right toes (resolved).

VITALS

Blood pressure: Slightly elevated in the office.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
MSK: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

Back x-ray: Normal, good bony alignment, no fracture present.

ASSESSMENT

1. Lumbar strain
2. Diabetes type 2
3. Hypertension
4. Osteoarthritis

PLAN

1. For lumbar strain, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.
2. For diabetes, increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day and repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
3. For hypertension, increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.
4. For osteoarthritis, continue monitoring knee without further workup at this time.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed for any concerns or changes in symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam, history of depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports doing relatively well, with some stress related to moving his daughter into college. He has been managing his depression with Prozac and has not had any incidents in a while. His hypertension has been more of a struggle, but he is taking Norvasc regularly during the business week, with occasional forgetfulness on weekends. He experiences shortness of breath with exertion during his morning runs, particularly in humid conditions, and occasional chest pounding, but it usually resolves.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Depression
Hypertension
Lobectomy

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Negative for fever.
Respiratory: Positive for shortness of breath with exertion.
Cardiovascular: Occasional chest pounding during exercise.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 120/80
Heart rate: Normal

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower extremity edema.
Head: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT

1. Depression: Well-managed with Prozac 20 mg daily.
2. Hypertension: Controlled with Norvasc, blood pressure within normal range.
3. Prior lobectomy: No current issues, chest X-ray normal.

PLAN

1. Continue Prozac 20 mg daily for depression management. Refill prescription.
2. Encourage patient to maintain regular medication schedule for hypertension, including weekends.
3. No further follow-up needed for lobectomy.
4. Order echocardiogram to evaluate systolic ejection murmur.
5. Order routine blood work.
6. Follow up with patient through the patient portal regarding test results.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right index finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of right index finger pain. She reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her ski pole strap got caught on her finger, causing it to bend back. The incident occurred on Sunday.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of constipation.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Miralax for constipation.

SURGICAL HISTORY

Patient had an appendectomy at age 18.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Right index finger:
- Tenderness over the distal phalanx and joint
- No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint
- Pain with flexion
- Able to bend and extend finger
- Able to touch thumb with finger

RESULTS

X-ray of the right index finger: No fractures observed, normal alignment.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right index finger contusion.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with tenderness and pain in the distal phalanx and joint of the right index finger after a skiing incident. X-ray shows no fractures.
- Medical Treatment: Provide an aluminum foam splint for the finger. Prescribe Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. Instruct the patient to follow up if symptoms do not improve within a week.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a pleasant 65-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of iron deficiency anemia. The patient was referred by Diane Nelson. She was diagnosed with anemia in 12-2019 when she was unable to donate blood. The patient has been dealing with anemia since she was 13 years old. She reports feeling fatigued, feverish with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. The patient also reports increased anxiety and depression. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was 5-6 years ago with no significant findings. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

General: Fatigue, feverish with chills.
Respiratory: Shortness of breath, wheezing.
Neurological: Headaches.
Psychiatric: Increased anxiety and depression.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient is alert and oriented.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm.
Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT

Iron deficiency anemia.

PLAN

1. Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily with orange juice for the next 12 weeks to improve iron absorption.
2. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate after 12 weeks.
3. Schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
4. Referral to hematologist Dr. Flores for further evaluation and management.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will schedule her upper endoscopy and colonoscopy and follow up with the hematologist. She will continue taking her iron pills with orange juice and call the clinic if she has any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents with worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches in the past. His past clinical history is unremarkable. Workup for headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where a pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago and worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, including fever, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has been bumping into door frames recently.

PAST HISTORY

Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient is a computer programmer and has been married for 25 years. He does not drink alcohol, smoke, or use recreational drugs.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None.

PHYSICAL EXAM

• Constitutional: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent.
• Neurological: Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS

MRI Brain with contrast (3/4/21): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. Ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

Labs (3/3/21): CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP are normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, all other results are normal.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.
• Worsening headaches.

PLAN

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with a benign-appearing pituitary adenoma, incidentally discovered during workup for worsening headaches. He is symptomatic with clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression, therefore surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa is indicated.

• Refer the patient to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test.
• Schedule surgery for transsphenoidal approach to remove the pituitary adenoma.
• Discuss risks and benefits of surgery with the patient.
• Follow up after surgery to monitor vision improvement and headache resolution.

INSTRUCTIONS

• Call with any questions or concerns.
• Schedule surgery and visual field test with the surgery scheduler.
• Follow up after surgery for evaluation of vision and headache improvement.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing. She reports that she experienced chest pain for four days in early October 2020. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. She also had difficulty swallowing during this time. The patient visited the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, but all results were normal. The ER suspected a GI issue and referred her to our clinic. The patient's chest pain and swallowing issues resolved three days after her ER visit. She has a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Positive for chest pain (resolved).
Gastrointestinal: Positive for difficulty swallowing (resolved), mild tenderness in the upper abdomen.
Psychiatric: Positive for anxiety related to job transition.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing with possible etiologies including GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal issues, and anxiety. Suspect anxiety attack related to job transition, with possible contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

PLAN

Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms with the patient. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. If symptoms recur, we will schedule an EGD to further evaluate her condition. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of her kidney function. She is a former 34 and 3-week-old twin. The patient has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon begin speech therapy. She has also seen a GI doctor, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient lives in Dallas, Georgia, with her family, including her twin sister and a 9-year-old brother with autism.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
Eyes: Small appearing.
Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms.
Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
Eyes: Small appearing.
Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms.
Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of her kidney function due to potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract associated with her chromosomal deletion syndrome.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
2. If the kidney ultrasound reveals abnormalities, determine next steps and future follow-up.
3. If follow-up is needed, schedule it at the town center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will complete the kidney ultrasound today. The doctor will call the family with the results. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up will be needed. If the ultrasound is abnormal, the patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment at the town center location.

CC:

Right wrist pain and swelling after a fall.

HPI:

Diana is a 35-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling after slipping on stairs while doing laundry. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She has not had any previous injuries to this arm.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Ibuprofen

EXAM:

Head and Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruits.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Upper Extremities: Normal range of motion in the left wrist. Right wrist shows pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Obvious swelling and bruising, tenderness on palpation, and bony crepitus present.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right wrist obtained on today's visit show a Colles' fracture.

IMPRESSION:

Right wrist Colles' fracture.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend a prescription for Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours as needed for pain. The patient will be provided with a wrist brace and scheduled for surgery. Post-surgery, the patient will wear the brace for 6 weeks and attend physical therapy. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in 4 weeks to assess progress and discuss the patient's upcoming vacation plans. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a pleasant patient with a past medical history of hypertension who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right knee pain. The onset of his pain began a week ago when he slipped and fell while working on his property. He reports feeling something pop during the fall. The patient describes his pain as a 4/10 when moving and states that it is mainly located on the inside of his knee. He has been taking ibuprofen for the swelling. 

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works from home and has not made significant changes to his diet.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.
Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee. Pain with flexion and extension. Edema around the knee and effusion present.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg

RESULTS

X-ray of the right knee reveals no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

1. Right knee MCL strain.
2. Hypertension.

PLAN

1. For the right knee MCL strain, prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice a day to help with swelling and pain. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times a day. Advise the patient to elevate the leg and avoid putting too much pressure on it.
2. For hypertension, continue with 20 mg of Lisinopril daily. Refer the patient to a nutritionist to help improve his diet and potentially reduce the need for medication in the future.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his knee pain does not improve, we will consider further evaluation and treatment options.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a 45-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of left shoulder pain that he has been experiencing for approximately three weeks. The patient is unsure of any specific injury that may have caused the pain but has been active and recently working on renovating his basement. He has difficulty reaching for objects and lifting, and experiences increased pain when attempting to reach overhead. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure, such as when lying on the affected shoulder. The patient has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours for pain relief, which helps to some extent but does not completely alleviate the pain.

PAST HISTORY

No significant past medical history.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Extra strength Tylenol.

ALLERGIES

No known allergies.

PHYSICAL EXAM

• Left shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion. Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints.
• Neurovascular: Capillary refill less than 3 seconds. Sensation intact to light touch.

RESULTS

Left shoulder X-ray: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

1. Order an MRI of the left shoulder to further evaluate the cause of the pain and rule out any additional issues.
2. Refer the patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks to help strengthen the shoulder muscles and improve range of motion.
3. Continue taking Tylenol as needed for pain relief.
4. If symptoms do not improve after physical therapy, consider a steroid injection for the shoulder to provide relief.
5. Schedule a follow-up visit after the completion of physical therapy to reassess the patient's progress.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will receive educational materials on physical therapy and what to expect during the treatment process. He will schedule a follow-up visit after completing physical therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a patient who presents today with occasional left knee pain that occurs less than once a day. She reports that the pain comes and goes quickly and does not last long. The pain is internal and involves the whole kneecap. She denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any pain medications for it. She is concerned about an upcoming trip where she will be doing a lot of walking and participating in line dancing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS

Farxiga, amlodipine, lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, metformin.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 72 bpm
Respirations: 16
Temperature: 98.2 F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily. Consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee and prevent further problems.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.

3. Diabetes mellitus.
- Medical Treatment: Order hemoglobin A1c to assess if adjustments to metformin are needed. Order lipid panel.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. She will follow up as needed and will be scheduled for an echocardiogram.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending. She presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports minimal fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and sore throat. Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting.

VITALS

Vitals look good, including oxygen levels.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Crackles in lungs bilaterally.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior side of the chest on the left side, possibly related to radiation.
Lower extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest x-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and radiation.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current regimen of cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy, and 45 Gy radiation. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor size for potential surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's cough and chest x-ray findings suggest radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: Likely due to inflammation in the esophagus from radiation.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow, to be used four times a day to help with swallowing and prevent dehydration and further weight loss.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Abnormal labs - low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kyle is a patient who presents today for evaluation of a low immunoglobulin A level, as noted by his primary care physician during a recent physical. The patient reports a history of frequent colds, particularly in the winter, which tend to linger for a long time. He denies any recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. He has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and has been started on metformin. The patient has no known family history of immune deficiencies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Respiratory: Reports frequent colds in the winter.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal infections or diarrhea.

VITALS

Vitals are within normal limits, including temperature.

PHYSICAL EXAM

• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
• Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, no guarding or rebound.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
   - Medical Reasoning: The patient has a slightly low immunoglobulin A level, which is a common immunodeficiency. He reports a history of frequent colds but no other significant infections. The likelihood of other immunodeficiencies is low in this case.
   - Additional Testing: We will order further blood work to check other antibodies.
   - Patient Education and Counseling: The patient should monitor for any infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control, as well as any changes in his abdominal tract, such as severe diarrhea. He should also inform any healthcare providers of his immunoglobulin A deficiency if he requires blood products in the future.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
   - Medical Reasoning: The patient has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and has been started on metformin.
   - Medical Treatment: Continue metformin as prescribed by the primary care physician.
   - Patient Education and Counseling: The patient should continue to monitor his blood sugar levels and adhere to a healthy diet, particularly given his family's ownership of a donut shop.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a patient who presents with right elbow pain that started approximately four days ago. The patient reports engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic, which may have contributed to the development of the pain. The pain is located on the inside of the right elbow and radiates slightly into the forearm. The patient denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been causing difficulty in lifting and performing daily activities. The patient has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Non-contributory.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Right elbow pain.
• All other systems reviewed and negative.

PHYSICAL EXAM

• Vitals: Stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Moderate tenderness to palpation over the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the right wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis of the right elbow.

PLAN

1. Rest and immobilization: The patient is advised to wear a sling while awake and avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
2. Ice application: Apply ice to the right elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Medication: Ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
4. Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week to assess progress.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to follow the treatment plan as prescribed and return for a follow-up appointment in one week.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a patient who presents today after a recent visit to the emergency department. He reports experiencing chest pain and shortness of breath while walking outside, which he initially dismissed. He also reports swelling in his ankles. He has a history of hypertension and has been taking Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc, but admits to occasionally missing doses. He has not been monitoring his diet closely and consumes salty foods, such as chips.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Chest pain and shortness of breath.
Respiratory: Shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Ankle swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 128/72 (in office)
Other vital signs within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck: No jugular venous distention.
Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
Lower extremities: Trace edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT

1. Chest pain and shortness of breath, likely due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
2. Hypertension.

PLAN

1. Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily.
2. Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily.
3. Continue Norvasc 5 mg once daily.
4. Consult with nutritionist for dietary advice.
5. Obtain a home blood pressure cuff and monitor blood pressure regularly.
6. Obtain a scale and weigh daily; call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.
7. Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.
8. Encourage patient to adhere to medication regimen and follow up with nutritionist.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up with nutritionist and adhere to medication regimen. Monitor blood pressure and weight regularly. Call if any concerns or significant changes occur.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain comes and goes, and when it comes, it is severe. The patient reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for the pain, but it has not provided relief. The patient feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a family history of kidney stones and has had them before but was able to pass them.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Kidney stones.

FAMILY HISTORY

Father had kidney stones.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Positive for right-sided abdominal pain, nausea, and burning sensation during urination. Denies vomiting, fever, or chills.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdominal: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen shows a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. The patient can continue to alternate with Tylenol.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain urine and collect the stone when it passes.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks. If the patient is still experiencing symptoms, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.
6. Instruct the patient to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a nonhealing foot ulcer on his right foot. He has had the ulcer for approximately six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The patient reports a foul smell, yellow drainage, and the blister becoming unroofed with soft, mushy skin underneath. He has been on antibiotics for six days, prescribed by his primary care physician. The patient has experienced fever, chills, and cramping in his calf muscle. He also reports a red streak along the inside of his calf muscle and difficulty catching his breath while walking around the house.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Diabetes, diabetic neuropathy, well-controlled with an A1C of 6.7.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Antibiotics (on day six of a ten-day course).

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, and foul odor. No bony exposure.
Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.

RESULTS

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's history and physical exam findings are consistent with a nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer with possible infection.
- Medical Treatment: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound. Perform debridement in the office today. Obtain a culture and consider different antibiotic therapy based on the results. Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf closely. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.

2. Diabetes management.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood sugars have been trending higher recently, and it is important to maintain good glycemic control to promote wound healing.
- Medical Treatment: Encourage the patient to follow up with their endocrinologist and continue monitoring blood sugars closely. Aim to keep the hemoglobin A1C below 7.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a 55-year-old male who presents with a tick bite on his right knee. He is unsure of when or where he got the tick bite but mentions spending time outdoors and going hunting recently. The tick bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. He denies fever, chills, joint pain, difficulty moving his knee, or problems walking. He has had tick bites in the past but has never been diagnosed with Lyme disease.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, Diabetes

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Endorses right knee discomfort.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: BP 122/70, HR 67, Temp 98.4 F
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over right patella. Pain to palpation of right anterior knee. Full range of motion of right knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite with concern for Lyme disease:
   - Medical Reasoning: Presence of bull's-eye rash and recent tick bite on right knee.
   - Additional Testing: Lyme titer and Western blot ordered.
   - Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.

2. Hypertension:
   - Medical Reasoning: Patient reports taking Lisinopril and checking blood pressure periodically.
   - Additional Testing: Lipid panel ordered.
   - Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.

3. Diabetes:
   - Medical Reasoning: Patient reports taking Metformin and checking blood sugars regularly, with average readings in the 120s.
   - Additional Testing: Hemoglobin A1c and basic metabolic panel ordered to assess long-term blood sugar control and kidney function.
   - Medical Treatment: Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed or if any new symptoms arise.
